cards.title: In pictures / Surfers in Australia tackle once-in-a-decade waves
cards.rawTitle: Surfers in Australia tackle once-in-a-decade waves

item.title: Monster swell: surfers in Australia tackle once-in-a-decade waves
item.trailText: Daredevils off the coast of Western Australia have been braving waves as tall as 18 metres. We sent the celebrated surfing photographer Russell Ord into the mix to document the infamous break known as ‘The Right’
item.standFirst: Daredevils in Western Australia have been braving waves as tall as 18 metres – more than five storeys – as a swell caused by a low-pressure system over the Indian Ocean swept the coast. One surfer broke his leg in Margaret River as he came crashing down ‘probably the biggest wave ever ridden in Australia’ and got pummelled by 15 metres of whitewater. We sent the celebrated surfing photographer Russell Ord into the mix to document the infamous break known as ‘The Right’

cards.title: Cricket / Several Ashes spots are still up for grabs, says Australia's Lehmann
cards.rawTitle: Several Ashes spots are still up for grabs, says Australia's Lehmann

item.title: Australia's Ashes team: several spots still up for grabs, says Lehmann
item.trailText: Australian cricket coach Darren Lehmann speaks to the media after his team took a comfortable victory over Kent
item.standFirst: Australian cricket coach Darren Lehmann speaks to the media after his team took a comfortable victory over Kent. Australia won their opening tour match by 255 runs in Canterbury today. The team now travels to Colchester for their second tour match against Essex, before the first Ashes Test next week. When asked to share who's in the first Test, Lehmann jokes 'Clarke, Smith'

cards.title: Ashes countdown / Highlights from Australia's warm-up match against Kent
cards.rawTitle: Highlights from Australia's warm-up match against Kent

item.title: Highlights from Australia's pre-Ashes warm-up match against Kent
item.trailText: Highlights from the Ashes tour warm-up match between Australia and Kent, in Canterbury
item.standFirst:
Highlights from the Ashes tour warm-up match between Australia and Kent, in Canterbury. Australia declared 332-4 on day three, claiming a leisurely 255-run victory over Kent despite resistance from Daniel Bell-Drummond, who hit an enchanting 127 from 112 balls. The Ashes series begins on Wednesday 8 July.

Click here for the match report

stillImage.caption: Mitchell Claydon of Kent hits a six as Australia's Brad Haddin and Michael Clarke look on Kent v Australia, Tour Match, Cricket, The Spitfire Ground, Canterbury, Kent, Britain. 28 Jun 2015 Photograph: Sarah Ansell/REX Shutterstock Photograph: Sarah Ansell/REX Shutterstock/Sarah Ansell/REX Shutterstock

cards.title: Tennis / Djokovic teases the crowd with shirt at Wimbledon warm-up
cards.rawTitle: Djokovic teases the crowd with shirt at Wimbledon warm-up

item.title: Novak Djokovic teases crowd with shirt at Wimbledon warm-up
item.trailText: Novak Djokovic, the world's top tennis player, performs a striptease during a Wimbledon warm-up match against Frenchman Richard Gasquet at Boodles
item.standFirst: Novak Djokovic, the world's top tennis player, performs a striptease during a Wimbledon warm-up match against Frenchman Richard Gasquet at Boodles tennis tournament in Stoke Poges, Buckinghamshire. Playing to the crowd, Djokovic peels off his white shirt in a break between sets, swinging the garment above his head before tossing it to the crowd. Gasquet eventually follows suit, upping the stakes with a courtside kiss

cards.title: In pictures / The best images from England v Canada
cards.rawTitle: The best images from England v Canada

item.title: Women's World Cup 2015: England v Canada
item.trailText: All the best images from Vancouver where England’s 2-1 win over the host nation put them into their first ever World Cup semi-final, where they will meet the reigning champions, Japan
item.standFirst: All the best images from Vancouver where England’s 2-1 win over the host nation put them into their first ever World Cup semi-final, where they will meet the reigning champions, Japan

displayImages.caption: Over at Wembley there’s a good luck message for the England team. Photograph: Claire Greenway/The FA via Getty Images
displayImages.credit: Claire Greenway/The FA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Over at Wembley there’s a good luck messagefor the England team
displayImages.cleanCaption: Over at Wembley there’s a good luck message for the England team.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Claire Greenway/The FA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: There is the odd England fan in the stadium. Photograph: Mike Hewitt/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: There is the odd England fan in the stadium
displayImages.cleanCaption: There is the odd England fan in the stadium.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: The two managers, John Herdman of Canada, left, and England’s Mark Sampson shake hands before kick-off. Photograph: Matthew Lewis/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The two managers, John Herdman of Canada, left, and England’s Mark Sampson shake hands ahead of kick-off
displayImages.cleanCaption: The two managers, John Herdman of Canada, left, and England’s Mark Sampson shake hands before kick-off.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Matthew Lewis/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Canada shade the opening exchanges with England looking a bit nervous. Here England’s goalkeeper Karen Bardsley punches the ball out clear under pressure from Canada’s Melissa Tancredi. Photograph: Anne-Marie Sorvin/USA Today Sports
displayImages.altText: Canada just shade the opening exchanges with England looking a bit nervous
displayImages.cleanCaption: Canada shade the opening exchanges with England looking a bit nervous. Here England’s goalkeeper Karen Bardsley punches the ball out clear under pressure from Canada’s Melissa Tancredi.

displayImages.caption: Then in the 11th minute Canada’s Lauren Sesselmann, left, gets her feet in a muddle and loses control of the ball in the middle of the park … Photograph: Darryl Dyck/AP
displayImages.altText: Canada’s Lauren Sesselmann, left, gets her feet in a muddle and loses control of the ball ....
displayImages.cleanCaption: Then in the 11th minute Canada’s Lauren Sesselmann, left, gets her feet in a muddle and loses control of the ball in the middle of the park …

displayImages.caption: Which England’s Jodie Taylor pounces on and hares off towards the Canada goal … Photograph: Darryl Dyck/AP
displayImages.altText: Which England’s Jodie Taylor pounces on and hares off towards the Canada goal …
displayImages.cleanCaption: Which England’s Jodie Taylor pounces on and hares off towards the Canada goal …

displayImages.caption: When she reaches the edge of the box she fires a pinpoint shot through the legs of Kadeisha Buchanan and past goalkeeper Erin McLeod to give England the lead. Photograph: Matt Kryger/USA Today Sports
displayImages.altText: England forward Jodie Taylor scores
displayImages.cleanCaption: When she reaches the edge of the box she fires a pinpoint shot through the legs of Kadeisha Buchanan and past goalkeeper Erin McLeod to give England the lead.

displayImages.caption: The England striker celebrates her goal to the disappointment of the Canadian fans. Taylor was making her first World Cup start just nine weeks after knee surgery. Photograph: Rich Lam/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The England striker celebrates her goal to the disappointment of the Canadian fans
displayImages.cleanCaption: The England striker celebrates her goal to the disappointment of the Canadian fans. Taylor was making her first World Cup start just nine weeks after knee surgery.

displayImages.caption: What a start for England captain Steph Houghton, centre, and her team – that was the Lionesses first attack of the match. Photograph: Ben Nelms/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: What a start for England captain Steph Houghton, centre, and her team, that was the Lionesses first attack of the match
displayImages.cleanCaption: What a start for England captain Steph Houghton, centre, and her team – that was the Lionesses first attack of the match.

displayImages.caption: Just three minutes later Lucy Bronze doubles England’s lead with a looping header. Fara Williams lumps a free-kick into the box where Bronze brushes off Allysha Chapman’s lacklustre challenge to loop a header goalwards. McLeod looked like she had it covered, but it dipped just underneath the bar and into the net. Photograph: Mike Hewitt/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Just three minutes later Lucy Bronze doubles England’s lead with a great looping header. Fara Williams lumps a free-kick into the box where Lucy Bronze brushes off Allysha Chapman’s lacklustre challenge to loop a header goalwards. Canada’s keeper Erin McLeod looked like she had it covered, but it dipped just underneath the bar and into the net
displayImages.cleanCaption: Just three minutes later Lucy Bronze doubles England’s lead with a looping header. Fara Williams lumps a free-kick into the box where Bronze brushes off Allysha Chapman’s lacklustre challenge to loop a header goalwards. McLeod looked like she had it covered, but it dipped just underneath the bar and into the net.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: England’s Jill Scott and Canada’s Chapman, right, fight for the ball in front of a crowd of 54,027. Photograph: Andy Clark/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: England’s Jill Scott and Canada’s Allysha Chapman, right fight for the ball
displayImages.cleanCaption: England’s Jill Scott and Canada’s Chapman, right, fight for the ball in front of a crowd of 54,027.

displayImages.caption: The England players wait for a free-kick to be launched into Canada’s penalty area as they look for a third goal. Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.credit: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The England players wait for a free-kick to be launched into Canada’s penalty area as they look for a third goal
displayImages.cleanCaption: The England players wait for a free-kick to be launched into Canada’s penalty area as they look for a third goal.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Christine Sinclair attempts to go past the England defender Laura Bassett as Canada attempt to get back into the game. Photograph: Anne-Marie Sorvin/USA Today Sports
displayImages.altText: Christine Sinclair attempts to go past England defender Laura Bassett as Canada attempt to get back into the game
displayImages.cleanCaption: Christine Sinclair attempts to go past the England defender Laura Bassett as Canada attempt to get back into the game.

displayImages.caption: Sinclair does indeed get her side back in the game just before half-time when she capitalises on a mistake by Bardsley. After some lovely approach play from Canada, Ashley Lawrence fires the ball low into the box which Bardsley spills and Sinclair is there to pounce.  Photograph: Rich Lam/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Sinclair does indeed get her side back in the game just before half-time when she capitalises on a mistake by England keeper Karen Bardsley. After some lovely approach play from Canada, and Ashley Lawrence worked it to the left side, where Melissa Tancredi was in a ton of space. Bardsley couldn’t handle Tancredi’s cross, and Sinclair was there to pounce
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sinclair does indeed get her side back in the game just before half-time when she capitalises on a mistake by Bardsley. After some lovely approach play from Canada, Ashley Lawrence fires the ball low into the box which Bardsley spills and Sinclair is there to pounce.

displayImages.caption: The home crowd are in raptures. Canada are still in this game as at half-time it’s England 2-1 Canada. Photograph: Ben Nelms/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The home crowd are in raptures
displayImages.cleanCaption: The home crowd are in raptures. Canada are still in this game as at half-time it’s England 2-1 Canada.

displayImages.caption: Early in the second half Siobhan Chamberlain replaces Bardsley to make her first World Cup appearance despite having been to three tournaments. Bardsley left the pitch clutching her right eye which was swollen. Photograph: Darryl Dyck/AP
displayImages.altText: Early in the second half Siobhan Chamberlain replaces Karen Bardsley to make her first World Cup appearance despite having been to three tournaments. Bardsley left the pitch clutching her right eye which was swollen quite badly
displayImages.cleanCaption: Early in the second half Siobhan Chamberlain replaces Bardsley to make her first World Cup appearance despite having been to three tournaments. Bardsley left the pitch clutching her right eye which was swollen.

displayImages.caption: Just before the hour mark McLeod keeps Canada in the game with a fantastic diving save to claw away Taylor’s curling effort which was heading inside the far post. Photograph: Rich Lam/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Just before the hour mark Erin McLeod keeps Canada in the game with a fantastic diving save to claw away Jodie Taylor’s curling effort which was heading inside the far post
displayImages.cleanCaption: Just before the hour mark McLeod keeps Canada in the game with a fantastic diving save to claw away Taylor’s curling effort which was heading inside the far post.

displayImages.caption: Buchanan shields the ball from Taylor. Photograph: Christopher Morris/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Kadeisha Buchanan shields the ball from Jodie Taylor
displayImages.cleanCaption: Buchanan shields the ball from Taylor.

displayImages.caption: England’s Williams attempts to divert the ball away from the onrushing Tancredi. Photograph: Matt Kryger/USA Today Sports
displayImages.altText: England;’s Fara Williams attempts to divert the ball away from the onrushing Melissa Tancredi
displayImages.cleanCaption: England’s Williams attempts to divert the ball away from the onrushing Tancredi.

displayImages.caption: McLeod uses her fingertips to good effect again as she claws the ball away from danger whilst Jill Scott and Allysha Chapman, right, look on  Photograph: Rich Lam/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: McLeod uses her fingertips to good effect again as she claws the ball away from danger whilst Jill Scott and Allysha Chapman, right, look on
displayImages.cleanCaption: McLeod uses her fingertips to good effect again as she claws the ball away from danger whilst Jill Scott and Allysha Chapman, right, look on

displayImages.caption: With 10 minutes to go Sophie Schmidt blazes over the bar from eight yards out. No wonder she’s reacting like that, it was a great chance to put Canada back on level pegging. Photograph: Ben Nelms/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: With ten minutes to go Sophie Schmidt blazes over the bar from eight yards out. No wonder she's reacting like that, it was a great chance to put Canada back on level pegging
displayImages.cleanCaption: With 10 minutes to go Sophie Schmidt blazes over the bar from eight yards out. No wonder she’s reacting like that, it was a great chance to put Canada back on level pegging.

displayImages.caption: As the clock ticks down Adriana Leon forages into the box searching for an equaliser but is crowded out by the England defence before she can get a shot away.  Photograph: Mike Hewitt/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Adriana Leon forages into the box but is crowded out by the England defence before she can get a shot away
displayImages.cleanCaption: As the clock ticks down Adriana Leon forages into the box searching for an equaliser but is crowded out by the England defence before she can get a shot away.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: The England players continue to defend resolutely for the final few minutes and the final whistle signals a victory which sends them into their first World Cup semi-final. Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.credit: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The England players continue to defend resolutely for the final few minutes and the final whistle signals a victory which sends them into their first World Cup semi-final

displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.altText: Canada’s goalkeeper Erin McLeod is dejected ...

image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images

image.caption: Christine Sinclair attempts to go past the England defender Laura Bassett as Canada attempt to get back into the game. Photograph: Anne-Marie Sorvin/USA Today Sports
image.altText: Christine Sinclair attempts to go past England defender Laura Bassett as Canada attempt to get back into the game
image.cleanCaption: Christine Sinclair attempts to go past the England defender Laura Bassett as Canada attempt to get back into the game.

image.caption: Sinclair does indeed get her side back in the game just before half-time when she capitalises on a mistake by Bardsley. After some lovely approach play from Canada, Ashley Lawrence fires the ball low into the box which Bardsley spills and Sinclair is there to pounce.  Photograph: Rich Lam/Getty Images
image.altText: Sinclair does indeed get her side back in the game just before half-time when she capitalises on a mistake by England keeper Karen Bardsley. After some lovely approach play from Canada, and Ashley Lawrence worked it to the left side, where Melissa Tancredi was in a ton of space. Bardsley couldn’t handle Tancredi’s cross, and Sinclair was there to pounce
image.cleanCaption: Sinclair does indeed get her side back in the game just before half-time when she capitalises on a mistake by Bardsley. After some lovely approach play from Canada, Ashley Lawrence fires the ball low into the box which Bardsley spills and Sinclair is there to pounce.

image.caption: The home crowd are in raptures. Canada are still in this game as at half-time it’s England 2-1 Canada. Photograph: Ben Nelms/Getty Images
image.altText: The home crowd are in raptures
image.cleanCaption: The home crowd are in raptures. Canada are still in this game as at half-time it’s England 2-1 Canada.

image.caption: Early in the second half Siobhan Chamberlain replaces Bardsley to make her first World Cup appearance despite having been to three tournaments. Bardsley left the pitch clutching her right eye which was swollen. Photograph: Darryl Dyck/AP
image.altText: Early in the second half Siobhan Chamberlain replaces Karen Bardsley to make her first World Cup appearance despite having been to three tournaments. Bardsley left the pitch clutching her right eye which was swollen quite badly
image.cleanCaption: Early in the second half Siobhan Chamberlain replaces Bardsley to make her first World Cup appearance despite having been to three tournaments. Bardsley left the pitch clutching her right eye which was swollen.

image.caption: Just before the hour mark McLeod keeps Canada in the game with a fantastic diving save to claw away Taylor’s curling effort which was heading inside the far post. Photograph: Rich Lam/Getty Images
image.altText: Just before the hour mark Erin McLeod keeps Canada in the game with a fantastic diving save to claw away Jodie Taylor’s curling effort which was heading inside the far post
image.cleanCaption: Just before the hour mark McLeod keeps Canada in the game with a fantastic diving save to claw away Taylor’s curling effort which was heading inside the far post.

image.caption: Buchanan shields the ball from Taylor. Photograph: Christopher Morris/Corbis
image.altText: Kadeisha Buchanan shields the ball from Jodie Taylor
image.cleanCaption: Buchanan shields the ball from Taylor.

image.caption: England’s Williams attempts to divert the ball away from the onrushing Tancredi. Photograph: Matt Kryger/USA Today Sports
image.altText: England;’s Fara Williams attempts to divert the ball away from the onrushing Melissa Tancredi
image.cleanCaption: England’s Williams attempts to divert the ball away from the onrushing Tancredi.

image.caption: McLeod uses her fingertips to good effect again as she claws the ball away from danger whilst Jill Scott and Allysha Chapman, right, look on  Photograph: Rich Lam/Getty Images
image.altText: McLeod uses her fingertips to good effect again as she claws the ball away from danger whilst Jill Scott and Allysha Chapman, right, look on
image.cleanCaption: McLeod uses her fingertips to good effect again as she claws the ball away from danger whilst Jill Scott and Allysha Chapman, right, look on

image.caption: With 10 minutes to go Sophie Schmidt blazes over the bar from eight yards out. No wonder she’s reacting like that, it was a great chance to put Canada back on level pegging. Photograph: Ben Nelms/Getty Images
image.altText: With ten minutes to go Sophie Schmidt blazes over the bar from eight yards out. No wonder she's reacting like that, it was a great chance to put Canada back on level pegging
image.cleanCaption: With 10 minutes to go Sophie Schmidt blazes over the bar from eight yards out. No wonder she’s reacting like that, it was a great chance to put Canada back on level pegging.

image.caption: As the clock ticks down Adriana Leon forages into the box searching for an equaliser but is crowded out by the England defence before she can get a shot away.  Photograph: Mike Hewitt/FIFA via Getty Images
image.altText: Adriana Leon forages into the box but is crowded out by the England defence before she can get a shot away
image.cleanCaption: As the clock ticks down Adriana Leon forages into the box searching for an equaliser but is crowded out by the England defence before she can get a shot away.
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/FIFA via Getty Images

image.caption: The England players continue to defend resolutely for the final few minutes and the final whistle signals a victory which sends them into their first World Cup semi-final. Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
image.credit: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
image.altText: The England players continue to defend resolutely for the final few minutes and the final whistle signals a victory which sends them into their first World Cup semi-final
image.cleanCaption: The England players continue to defend resolutely for the final few minutes and the final whistle signals a victory which sends them into their first World Cup semi-final.
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images

image.caption: Canada’s McLeod is dejected … Photograph: Rich Lam/Getty Images
image.altText: Canada’s goalkeeper Erin McLeod is dejected ...
image.cleanCaption: Canada’s McLeod is dejected …

image.caption: As are Sinclair and Lawrence. Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
image.credit: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images
image.altText: Christine Sinclair and Ashley Lawrence
image.cleanCaption: As are Sinclair and Lawrence.
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images

image.caption: The Canadian players join hands as they salute their fans. Photograph: Bob Frid/EPA
image.altText: The Canadian players join hands as they salute their fans.
image.cleanCaption: The Canadian players join hands as they salute their fans.

cards.title: The amazing world of sport / Paraglider flies into cable car ... on purpose
cards.rawTitle: Paraglider flies into cable car ... on purpose

item.title: Paraglider flies into moving cable car ... on purpose
item.trailText: Arnaud Longobardi, 43, flies into the open doors of a moving cable car, 150 metres above the ground, in the French Alps
item.standFirst:
Arnaud Longobardi, 43, flies into the open doors of a moving cable car, 150 metres above the ground, in the French Alps. For the stunt to work, Longobardi has to perfectly time his takeoff after the cable car leaves its dock, in order to enter its door at the precise point necessary - when it is briefly travelling horizontally rather than at an angle up or down - according to organisers

• Watch the full video here

cards.title: Cycling / Froome: I'm not looking for a stage win on Tour de France
cards.rawTitle: Froome: I'm not looking for a stage win on Tour de France

item.title: Chris Froome on the Tour de France: I'm not looking for a stage win
item.trailText: Chris Froome shares his thoughts ahead of this year's Tour de France, which begins in Utrecht on 4 July
item.standFirst: Chris Froome shares his thoughts ahead of this year's Tour de France, which begins in Utrecht on 4 July. Commenting on Team Sky's chances this year, Froome says everyone is in 'great condition' and motivated to win. He also addresses the International Cycling Union's decision to ban motor-homes during the race and its insistence that cyclists stay in official hotels
